Popagingapp.uk

Population aging web app

How much healthcare will our population need in five, ten, 20 years’ time? Looking into the future is challenging, but those planning publicly funded health services, whether in government departments, regional health systems, or local services must be ready with answers.

The Strategy Unit has developed an interactive tool to show how population aging and other demographic changes will impact the future need for different types of hospital services in your local area.

The demography of the UK is changing as people live longer, but the age and sex structure of local areas can differ greatly depending on where you are. Coastal areas in the South and East of England have the oldest populations. Big cities with large student communities and London Boroughs with large foreign-born populations have the youngest inhabitants.

By showing how populations are composed, and crucially how they are expected to change, population pyramids help bring these differences to life. Contrast the Christmas tree-shape of the Barking and Dagenham population with the rectangular-shape of Worcestershire.

The future shape of our population will be determined by trends in births, deaths, and migration. To help with decision-making the Office for National Statistics (ONS) publish population projections that tell us about the possible future size and makeup of our population. To assess and communicate the uncertainty associated with their projections the ONS construct alternative scenarios. For example, what if international migration declined from relatively high historical levels or what if women continued to have fewer children than in the past.

Choose from 10 variant projections (alongside the principal projection) and watch how the age and sex structure changes in your area to 2043.

The relationship between age and healthcare use

The increased likelihood of morbidity and mortality that comes with increasing age means use of healthcare tends to be higher among the old than the young. This is especially true for treatment of physical health conditions provided in hospitals.

The relationship between people’s age and their use of healthcare is best shown by ‘age-related activity profiles’, which plot the average number of treatments (e.g., hospital stays, A&E attendances etc.) per head of population against age.

Demand for services with the steepest profiles, like A&E visits by ambulance and unplanned admissions, will be most affected by population aging because the average age of patients in these groups is much higher than, for example, walk-in A&E visits or most outpatient services.

You can view the activity profiles for your local area across eleven service types covering all three main settings for hospital care (A&E, inpatients, and outpatients).

Modeling future healthcare activity

The primary driver of need for health and related services is the size and age structure of the population (European Commission, 2024). Therefore, a reasonable starting point might be to take the level of healthcare provided now and make adjustments based on expected changes in the size and age structure of the population served. In a typical modelling exercise, activity profiles like the ones shown above are multiplied by the respective age/sex population group in some future year.

However, while most types of healthcare activity increase with age, age itself is not the underlying cause; demand for and use of healthcare depends ultimately on health status and functional ability. It is entirely possible for a population to both age and become healthier. In such a scenario, future gains in life expectancy are spent in good health, resulting in a hypothetical future 75-year-old having better health than a 75-year-old today. The compression of morbidity hypothesis (Fries, 1980) has a long-established theoretical underpinning, and its popular interpretation lies behind headlines such as, ‘Is 60 is the new 50?’ (Levine, 2018). In a more dystopian future, average lifespan is prolonged, but the prevalence of chronic diseases and disabilities increases sharply (Gruenberg, 1977. Kramer, 1980).

Unpicking which of these paths population health will travel is far from straightforward. Health status is a multidimensional concept that does not lend itself to easy measurement. The evidence that does exist on long-term trends in health status whether it be prevalence of chronic conditions, disability, or self-assessed general health is mixed. Yet the question of how population health status will evolve in relation to changes in life expectancy—will the additional years of life that recent cohorts have gained (and stand to gain) be spent in good health or disability and frailty—is of great significance to those involved in decisions about future healthcare resource requirements.

Where high quality empirical evidence is missing decision-makers often seek out expert opinion. Fortunately, there are established procedures for obtaining and pooling analytical judgements from groups of experts. The most useful approaches allow for uncertainty to be quantified in the form of a probability distribution. In October 2022, a group of independent experts were asked for their view on the future health of the population in England. Broadly, the consensus view was that the most likely outcome was for the share of remaining life spent in good health (free of limiting long-standing illness) at age 65 years to fall slightly by 2035. However, there was a considerable degree of uncertainty around this central view. The group also judged the balance of risk to be asymmetrical with a greater chance that the decline in health status might be less than their central view or even that it might improve compared with the chances of it worsening by more than their central view. We use the probability distribution from this exercise to adjust our estimate of future healthcare activity.

You can view the results of our modeling for your local area across eleven different service types covering the three main settings for hospital care (A&E, inpatients, and outpatients) in 5-year steps to 2040. The charts explicitly show the uncertainty associated with how population health status might evolve. The progression from purple (more probable) to yellow (less probable) stripes portrays the frequency of outcomes from a Monte Carlo simulation. Uncertainty associated with how future trends in fertility, mortality and migration might affect the size and age structure of an area’s population can be explored by selecting one of 10 variant population projections.
